page.title: 17CHIDDINGLYE AND GRAVETYE
page.content: The path from the{White Hart Inn}to {West Hoathly}goes across the valley and through{Chiddinglye,}formerly the estate of the{Tudor ironmasters,}the {Michells.}The farmhouse dates from the 16th century with a 17th century barn. {Gravetye Woods,}in the care of the {Forestry Commission,}are well worth a visit. They are part of the old forest of the{Weald}and were largely replanted by the{famous gardener {William Robinson,}who lived in {Gravetye Manor}from 1884-1935 and also laid out the gardens. He planted more than 120,000 trees, including many unusual evergreens. There are many walks and a fine viewpoint about 1km from the carpark in{Vowels Lane.}The Manor is now a{hotel and country club but the gardens are open to the public on Tuesdays and Fridays from 10am to 5pm.
